narrative.narrative:
# Your 2024: A Punk Rock Odyssey (Mostly Featuring NOFX)

## The Year You Basically Married Fat Mike

Let's cut straight to it: You listened to **30,638 tracks** this year, and **13,306 of them were NOFX**. That's 43% of your entire year. You spent more time with Fat Mike than most people spend with their actual friends. You dedicated **518 hours** to NOFX alone – that's literally 21.5 days straight of punk rock bliss.

You played "The Decline" **108 times**. You know, that 18-minute epic? That's **33.9 hours** of your life committed to a single song. Some people binge-watch Netflix. You binge-listen to one track that's longer than most TV episodes.

## The 1-2 AM Philosophy Hour

Your peak listening hour was **1-2 AM** with 2,403 plays. While normal humans were sleeping, you were having your 43rd late-night encounter with "Linoleum" (your certified Late Night Anthem™). There's something beautifully unhinged about blasting punk rock in the wee hours, and you committed to it **hard**.

## That One Day in June

On June 2nd, 2025, something possessed you to play "The Decline" **18 times in one day**. That's 5.4 hours of the same song. Were you okay? Did you lose a bet? Were you trying to unlock some secret punk rock enlightenment? We may never know, but respect.

## Your Supporting Cast

Chumbawamba came in at #2 with 3,225 plays, proving you appreciate bands that get knocked down but get up again (we all saw what you did there). Screeching Weasel, The Dead Milkmen, and Propagandhi rounded out your top 5, confirming that your music taste peaked somewhere in the mid-90s punk scene and you're absolutely fine with that.

## The Summer Silence

August 2024: **1 play**. ONE. What happened? Did you finally go outside? Did someone take your phone? Were you in witness protection? After months of 5,000+ plays, you basically went radio silent. Then September rolled around and you came roaring back with 887 plays like nothing happened.

## The Completionist

You explored **360 unique albums** but kept returning home to "45 or 46 Songs That Weren't Good Enough to Go on Our Other Records" (1,645 plays). You literally preferred NOFX's reject pile to most other bands' greatest hits. That's either profound loyalty or Stockholm syndrome, and honestly, it's probably both.

## The Verdict

You maintained a **164-day listening streak**, spinning tracks every single day for over five months. You averaged **84 tracks per day**. You listened to **1,309 hours** of music total. You are either the world's most dedicated punk rock archivist, a very patient person, or someone who really, *really* hates silence.

In 2024, while others were discovering new genres and expanding their horizons, you looked at NOFX's entire discography and said "Yeah, this'll do." And you know what? That's punk as hell.

**Your 2024 in three words:** Fat Mike Forever. 🎸

personality.tagline: 43% of your year was Fat Mike yelling at you
personality.description: You've achieved what scientists call 'punk rock monogamy' - 13,306 plays of NOFX means you listened to them for 518 hours, or roughly 21.5 DAYS straight. You've heard 'The Decline' 108 times, which is 33.9 hours of the same 18-minute song. Most people have a top artist; you have a lifestyle commitment. Your 74 total artists suggests you occasionally remember other bands exist, then immediately return to Fat Mike like a homing pigeon in studded leather. You're either writing a dissertation on NOFX or you've simply achieved punk rock enlightenment and realized all other music is irrelevant. Your 1-2 AM peak listening hours suggest you're either a night shift worker or conducting very aggressive insomnia therapy.
personality.spirit_animal: A mohawked lemming that only follows one leader off one very specific cliff

roasts: You listened to NOFX 13,306 times this year. Even Fat Mike is telling you to diversify your portfolio.
You played 'The Decline' 108 times - that's 33.9 HOURS of a single song. NOFX wrote it as a joke about punk rock excess and you took it as a personal challenge.
43% of your total listening time was NOFX. At this point, you're not a fan, you're providing their retirement fund.
Your top album is literally called '45 or 46 Songs That Weren't Good Enough' - even NOFX is roasting your taste FROM INSIDE your playlist.
Only 74 unique artists all year? Your Spotify Wrapped looks like a 90s Warped Tour lineup that got lost in time and refused to leave the parking lot.

aura.description: Your aura radiates raw, unapologetic energy—the sonic equivalent of a 3am basement show that never ends. With NOFX dominating nearly half your listening time, you've essentially mainlined Fat Wreck Chords directly into your veins. You're the person who knows every word to 'The Decline' (all 18+ minutes) and considers it normal to loop it 108 times in a year. Your crimson aura pulses with bratty humor, political snark, and the kind of DIY dedication that racks up 30,000+ plays without blinking. You don't just listen to punk—you live in it, breathe it, and probably argue about it online. Late nights are your domain (peak hour: 1am), fueled by sarcastic anthems and the eternal question: 'Did NOFX actually get worse live?' Your music taste is a battle vest covered in patches—chaotic, confrontational, and worn with absolute pride.

superlatives.award: Most Likely to Start a NOFX Cover Band (and Only Play NOFX)
superlatives.reason: 13,306 NOFX plays out of 30,638 total tracks - that's 43% of your entire year dedicated to one band. Fat Mike would be proud (or concerned).

superlatives.award: The 'I'll Sleep When I'm Dead' Award
superlatives.reason: Peak listening hour is 1 AM with 2,403 plays in the wee hours. 'Linoleum' played 43 times after midnight because nothing says insomnia like skatepunk.

superlatives.award: Most Likely to Know Every Word to an 18-Minute Song
superlatives.reason: Played 'The Decline' 108 times for a grand total of 33.9 hours. That's almost a full-time job of listening to one epic punk opera.
Your most-played album is literally called '45 or 46 Songs That Weren't Good Enough to Go on Our Other Records' with 1,645 plays. You're out here defending the B-sides.

superlatives.award: Best Impression of a Broken Jukebox at a Dive Bar
superlatives.reason: Played 'The Decline' 18 times in a single day on June 2nd. That's 5.4 straight hours of the same song. Even Fat Wreck Chords is like 'maybe take a break?'

hot_takes: You listened to NOFX for 43% of your ENTIRE YEAR. That's not a music taste, that's a parasocial relationship with Fat Mike.
Playing 'The Decline' 108 times means you spent 34 hours listening to ONE song. You could've learned actual guitar in that time instead of air-guitaring the same 18-minute track.
Only 74 unique artists in 30,638 plays? My Spotify Wrapped has more diversity than your entire musical identity. This isn't loyalty, it's Stockholm Syndrome.
You played 'Linoleum' 132 times and 'The Decline' 18 times in one day. Either you're the world's biggest NOFX fan or you've forgotten how the skip button works.
Chumbawamba at #2 with 3,225 plays... You're not just getting knocked down and getting up again, you're stuck in an infinite loop of 90s nostalgia and can't escape.

suggestions: You listened to 'The Decline' 18 times in one day... clearly you're ready for the full Propagandhi discography deep-dive. Start with 'Less Talk, More Rock' and don't come up for air.
43% of your year was NOFX. At this rate, 2025 will be 'Fat Mike's Guest Bedroom Playlist' – but throw in some Lagwagon, Strung Out, and No Use for a Name to complete your Fat Wreck Chords bingo card.

Peak listening at 1-3 AM means you're either extremely nocturnal or avoiding responsibilities. Either way, The Lawrence Arms and Dead to Me are perfect 2 AM companions for whatever you're going through.
You've exhausted NOFX's catalog (13,306 plays?!), so 2025 is the year you finally admit you also like Bad Religion, Pennywise, and early Offspring. It's okay, we won't tell Fat Mike.
With Chumbawamba as #2, you clearly appreciate punk with substance. Time to explore Crass, Conflict, and Subhumans – less ska, more anarcho-punk manifestos.
